title: Raheem Sterling admits Liverpool move was 'new beginning from God' after tough upbringing in London
text:

Raheem Sterling has told of how moving to Liverpool was like “God gave me a new beginning” after a tough start to life in London.

The Manchester City winger, 24, revealed he was in some dangerous situations growing up in the capital, which he moved to from Jamaica aged five.

He said: “You grow up in some of these areas and at any moment, something can kick off. You have kids and they might see you’re from a different area and want to take something off you.

“You think, ‘No, I’m not giving it to you’ and it gets out of hand for no reason. There have been many times in London when things have got sticky.”

(Image: Getty)

(Image: Harrow Observer)

Sterling, who grew up in Wembley, started at QPR before joining Liverpool in 2010, aged 15.

He said: “I loved every minute of it. It was probably the best thing that could happen – changing my space, going into a new environment. It was like God gave me a new beginning.”

Sterling won a place in the England team before joining Manchester City in 2015, where he has flourished.

But he told Four Four Two magazine abuse from fans and critics hit him hard when he first played for the Three Lions.

(Image: Steve Bainbridge)

(Image: Instagram)

He said: “I just believe people didn’t want me in the national team. It puts you in a low place. You want to be the best you can be for your national team but if you don’t have that love, which I didn’t think I was getting...

“I had to show them I wanted to be there.

“I believe people understand me now.”

The full interview with Sterling is in issue 306 of Four Four Two, out now.
description: England star Raheem Sterling admits he was in some dangerous situations growing up in the capital
